entry.title: Re: Automatic generation of proforma invoice
entry.content:
To answer your question, "how can we stop it from recreating automatically", by default, SAP doesn’t track whether a proforma invoice has already been created, because proforma invoices don’t update accounting. They’re often used for customs, export, or internal documentation. So unless you build a logic to flag or exclude processed documents, the job may regenerate them.

In order to address this requirement automatically, couple of options are there

Option 1: Use Output Status or Custom Flag

  • After creating a proforma invoice, update a custom field or output status on the delivery or sales order
  • Modify the job selection logic to exclude documents with that flag

Option 2: Custom Table to Track Proforma Status

  • Create a Z-table to store delivery/sales order numbers for which proforma invoices have been created
  • Before job execution, check this table and skip already processed entries

entry.title: Re: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and...
entry.content:
Yes with Option A to make it work, without blocking customer creation in real DCs, you need to:

reverse the VOR1 Mapping Logic. Instead of pointing D1 → D0, you should:

  • point D0 → D1
  • This way, materials maintained in D0 are usable in D1, but customers must exist in D1 explicitly

This flips the fallback logic:

  • Materials must be maintained in D0, usable in D1
  • Customers must be maintained in D1, not inherited from D0

entry.title: Lean Service Procurement for Project Network in SAP S/4 Hana
entry.content:
Lean Services in S/4HANA provide a lightweight, Fiori-driven approach to project service procurement, reducing overhead from large service specs while enabling fast SES creation and automated GR after approval. In this post I share a step-by-step guide that covers: configuration, WBS & activity set up, adding service components to WBS/Network, PR behavior options, PO creation, creating Lean Service Entry Sheets in Fiori, budget impact, and available tables for reporting (MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM, SGBT_NTE_CONT).

🔑Why Lean Services?

  1. Simplifies service procurement with a lightweight structure
  2. Enables faster creation of Service Entry Sheets (SES) directly in FIori apps.
  3. Integrates seamlessly with Project Systems (PS) and Materials Management (MM) for project-based external/internal services
  4. Automates Goods Receipt (GR) postings after SES approval, reducing manual work

🧩 Difference - Normal Services (Item category 'D' vs. Lean Service

AspectNormal Service (Item Category D)Lean Service Procurement
Service SpecificationRequires detailed Service Master, free-text. Often involves hierarchical service lines with limits.No need service specifications. Service items are handled like Materials- simple structure with fewer fields
Service EntryManager via ML81N (Classical)Fiori based SES with simplified UI
ReportingBased on classic service tables (ESLH, ESLL, ESKL)

Based on new Lean service tables MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM

Pre-requisite Configuration (what to set up before you start)

Step 1: Enable Procurement Mode for Project Profile

Path: SPRO > Project Systems > Structures > Operative Structures > Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) > Maintain Procurement Mode for Project Profile

This setting enables project WBS elements to create procurement items

Step 2: User Setting - Activate Service Option

In the Project builder user options (Options), make sure the service check box is enabled so the "Create -> Component -> Service" option appears. 

Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Create Project & WBS (App: project Builder Over / CJ20N)

  1. Open Project Builder (Fiori Project Builder Overview or CJ20N)
  2. Enter Project ID and description -> create WBS elements (level 1, Level 2 as required)

Step 2: Create Activity 

  1. Right click on a WBS element -> Create -> Activity (Internal) (or External depending on business). Activities represent tasks for which services will be procured.

Step 3: Add Service as a Component

  1. Right click the Activity -> Create -> Component ->Service (this option is available only after the project procurement config and user check are set)

Step 3: Maintain Purchase Data in the Service Item

  1. Material/Service: Enter service material or free description as applicable
  2. Item category: use N (non-sock item) when using this approach
  3. Procurement: set to PF (PF = PR for WBS)

Under purchase data: enter Requirement Quantity, Purchasing Group, Price, G/L Account, Material Group, etc.

Step 4: Purchase Requisition Mode (important choice)

  1. Choose PR creation behavior for the project:
    1. Never - PR will not be auto-created (can be created later).
    2. From Release - PR created only after the project/WBS is released.
    3. Immediately - PR created when the project is saved.
  2. Save the project and then check the Purchase Data tab for the generated PR number (if PR creation mode triggers it)

Step 5: Verify Purchase Requisition

  1. Use Display Purchase Requisitions app (or ME53N) to validate PR contents (account assignment to Network/WBS, quantities, price, etc.)

Step 6: Create Purchase Order (App: Manage Purchase Orders/ME21N)

  1. Create PO using PR as reference. Fill Document Type, Supplier, Purchasing Org, Company Code, and add PR items to the PO. Check item details and post the PO.

Step 7: Create Service Entry Sheet - Lean Services (Fiori App)

  1. Open Manage Service Entry Sheets - Lean Services.
  2. Select the PO/line and open items. Fill Account Assignment Data, add any Header Note and Item text, and attach supporting documents (in attachments tab). Click create to post SES.

Header Note

Item text, and attach supporting documents (in attachments tab). Click create to post SES.

Step 8: Approval & Automatic GR

  1. After SES approval (depending on workflow), a Goods Receipt (GR) posting will be automated which updates PO history and posts financials (commitment ->actual) Check PO History tab to confirm.

Step 9: Budgeting (what to check and where)

  1. Budget report transaction: S_ALR_87013558 - run by Controlling Area + Project Definition to see Assigned / Commitment / Actual budget lines.
  2. In this case: Assigned = 500 SAR, Commitment = 400 SAR (after SES posting commitment decreased by 100), Actual = 100 SAR.

Step 10: Reporting (what to check and where)

Tables useful for reporting: MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM (SES header & item), and Notes table SGBT_NTE_COUNT (stores SES/PO notes).

(Note 1: You can build a query based on this information, or create a custom report combining MMPUR_SES_HEADER + MMPPUR_SES_ITEM tables and also the SGBT_NTE_CONT)

(Note 2: Refer SAP note: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3503538)

Table: SGBT_NTE_CONT

Table: MMPUR_SES_HEADER

Table: MMPUR_SES_ITEM

 

If you found this guide helpful, don’t miss my other SAP MM WM blogs covering real-world automation, configuration tips, and best practices for procurement, inventory management, and warehouse management.

Click to view other SAP MM WM Blogs - SAP Community

 

Regards,

Mannem Leelamohan

entry.title: EUDR Made Simple: What Downstream Operators and Traders Really Need
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities such as cocoa, coffee, soy, palm oil, rubber, cattle, and timber. From December 2025, large companies must comply, with SMEs following by June 2026.

For first-time operators placing goods on the EU market, compliance is extensive. They must collect detailed information (Article 9), run risk assessments (Article 10), and mitigate risks (Article 11) before submitting a Due Diligence Statement (DDS). But for companies further down the chain: downstream operators and traders, the requirements are different, and often misunderstood.

Misinterpreting these obligations can lead to wasted effort. Some companies are preparing to invest in full geospatial risk analysis when all they really need is a robust system for DDS referencing. 

 Figure 1. EUDR Roles

 

What the regulation actually requires

According to EUDR and the Commission FAQ (3.4):

  • Downstream non-SME operators and non-SME traders may refer to due diligence already performed earlier in the supply chain by including the reference and verification numbers of upstream DDS.
  • Their obligations are to:
    1. Ascertain that due diligence was exercised upstream (Article 4(9)). This means collecting DDS reference and verification numbers from direct suppliers and checking they are valid in the Information System ‘TRACES’.
    2. Submit their own DDS in TRACES, referencing the upstream DDS numbers they received.
    3. Maintain a due diligence system (Article 12) to ensure they can prove upstream due diligence was exercised.

In practice, this means downstream operators and traders do not have to repeat Article 9 information gathering or Articles 10–11 risk assessment/mitigation — those obligations remain with the first operator. Their core task is DDS management: collecting, referencing, submitting, and storing.

 

The scope of work

The key challenges for downstream players are operational:

  • Collecting and validating potentially thousands of DDS reference numbers from suppliers.
  • Ensuring those numbers are valid in TRACES (the system automatically checks up to 2,000 at once).
  • Submitting their own DDS correctly, referencing the chain of upstream DDS.
  • Retaining records for at least five years for audit.

 Figure 2. TRACES connection (simulation for reference)

 

How SAP Green Token makes it simple

SAP Green Token provides exactly what downstream operators and traders need:

  • DDS collection and referencing
    Capture upstream DDS reference and verification numbers, automatically validate them in TRACES, and attach them to your own DDS.
  • Automated TRACES integration
    Submit DDS with referenced upstream numbers directly into TRACES. No re-keying, no manual uploads.
  • Centralized compliance system
    Keep DDS records, mandates, and reference chains in one secure, auditable system, ready for inspection.
  • Multi-entity support
    Manage DDS for multiple subsidiaries, commodities, or supply chains at once.
  • Audit-ready reporting
    Instantly demonstrate to authorities that you’ve ascertained upstream due diligence and correctly submitted your DDS.

 

 Figure 3. Outbound Deliveries Connected to TRACES in Green Token

 

A practical example

Consider a large EU retailer selling chocolate. The cocoa beans have already been subject to due diligence and a DDS has been filed by the importer. The retailer, as a downstream trader, does not redo due diligence on the beans. Instead, they:

  1. Collect the DDS reference numbers from their supplier.
  2. Submit their own DDS in TRACES, referencing those numbers.
  3. Store the records for five years.

With Green Token, this process is automated end-to-end, reducing administrative effort and lowering compliance risk.

Downstream operators and traders do not need full Article 10 and 11 systems. Their obligation is narrower but still critical: manage and reference DDS correctly.

SAP Green Token is designed to make this easy with automated TRACES integration, reference validation, and audit-ready records.

👉 If you’re a downstream operator or trader preparing for EUDR, focus on what really matters: robust DDS management. Learn more about SAP Green Token here.

entry.title: Re: Need to directly scrap the return stock in one -step
entry.content:
Being a new comer, please go through the below thoroughly and understand how a new discussion can be created.

Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already.
If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems.
When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself.
Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

Now, coming to your post, you have not explained your requirement clearly. In order to assist in a better way, please answer the following:

  • What type of return stock are you referring to? Customer returned stock or internal return stock?
  • Where is the return stock currently located? Is it in blocked stock, quality inspection, or unrestricted use?
  • Is the stock already posted back to inventory? Or are you trying to scrap it before posting the return?
  • Are you using a specific movement type or transaction? For example, are you using MIGO, MB1A, or a custom Fiori app?
  • Do you want to scrap the stock without creating a separate return or inspection document? This helps determine if a one-step process is feasible.

entry.title: Quality Gates in SAP Activate for SAP Concur Road Map
entry.content:
Our SAP Activate road maps are designed to grow alongside your journey. Through the SAP Activate team’s blog, you can see how they continuously evolve—never static, always adapting. This ongoing refinement ensures you receive the right guidance, whether you’re implementing a single SAP solution or an entire suite of products.

Building on this commitment, our SAP Activate for SAP Concur road map now includes a dedicated Quality Gate Checklist tailored specifically for SAP Concur projects. Accessible directly in the Road Map Viewer and in SAP Cloud ALM, it brings greater structure and clarity to your implementation process.

This checklist is essential for ensuring project success. It provides a structured framework to evaluate progress at key milestones. It enables teams to verify that critical deliverables meet predefined standards before advancing to the next phase, helping to mitigate potential risks. Through its structured approach, the checklist promotes transparency and accountability while instilling confidence that the project remains aligned with business objectives.

In this way, it serves as both a safeguard and a guide, helping organizations deliver implementations more efficiently, consistently, and with higher-quality outcomes. As illustrated below, this is reflected in action in the Road Map Viewer and SAP Cloud ALM.

At the end of each phase, you will find the task for Quality Gate.

In SAP Cloud ALM, once we have created a project with the SAP Concur road map, the quality gates will be available in the Quality Gates App. See sequence below:

entry.title: Re: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: seguridad reforzada, IA aplicada y nuevas alianzas estratégicas
entry.content:
La federación de datos es una herramienta muy potente cuando se gestiona adecuadamente. Pero para ello, es fundamental ser transparentes sobre cómo funciona el sistema: cómo se traduce una consulta al sistema fuente, qué funciones son compatibles con el push down, etc.

Actualmente, faltan herramientas que faciliten esta gestión. Por ejemplo, una simple combinación de funciones como LEFT o TO_VARCHAR en una consulta puede impedir que se realice el push down del filtro o cálculo. Esto puede provocar que el sistema intente traer 100 millones de filas desde BigQuery para aplicar el cálculo o filtro en Datasphere.

Y si esto ocurre cuando lo hace un diseñador, imaginemos el riesgo de dejar una tabla remota federada disponible para su uso en un dashboard. Si no existen herramientas de control, y tienen gran volúmen de datos (como suele ser el caso en BigQuery) para mi  representan un peligro si se dejan en manos de usuarios finales, y son algo a vigilar incluso cuando las utilizan usuarios técnicos.

Creo firmemente en que la federación puede ser una muy buena herramienta, de hecho hay un mercado maduro con empresas especializadas en ese mundo, y espero que se den pasos en favor de mejorarlo en la plataforma.

Saludos.

entry.title: Re: Need to directly scrap the return stock in one -step
entry.content:
There is no standard movement type or process that allows you to post customer return stock directly to scrap in one step and bypassing inventory receipt. SAP requires the return to be accounted for first, then scrapped, to ensure proper valuation, traceability, and compliance.

Could of workarounds are there which will meet your requirement.

  • Create a custom Z-transaction that posts the return with movement type 651 to blocked or QI stock. Immediately triggers a scrap posting (e.g., 551 from that same stock). This is a two-step process under the hood, but one-step for the user. You can use BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE twice in sequence with proper checks
  • The other option is Workflow automation. By this approach, keep the standard two-step process. Post return to BL or QL. Auto-trigger scrap via workflow or background job. This avoids custom movement types but still achieves automation.

If automation is the goal rather than true one-step posting, a workflow-based two-step may be safer and easier to maintain.

entry.title: Integrating SAP ECC with Snowflake using SAP Datasphere as a pass-through
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

We have a requirement to use SAP Datasphere as a pass-through layer for integrating SAP ECC data into Snowflake, and we are seeking help and guidance from the community/SAP experts.

Details are below,

Landscape

  • Source: SAP ECC 6.0 EHP7 (Oracle DB)

  • Target: Snowflake

  • Middleware: SAP Datasphere (as pass-through, since tenant isn’t available in UAE region)

  • License: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) already procured

Requirement

  • Leverage existing ECC extractors to ingest ECC data into Snowflake through Datasphere.

Approaches identified

  1. ABAP Connection + DMIS add-on → Enable ODP extractors & Replication Flows → Datasphere → ADLS → Snowflake

  2. ECC Connection exposing ODP extractors via Remote Tables → Datasphere → Azure Data Factory → ADLS → Snowflake

Open Questions 

  1. Can BW Bridge be used only as pass-through (without staging) to expose ECC data directly to Snowflake?

  2. Any recommendations or best practices to expose ECC 6.0 EHP7 (Oracle DB) data to 3rd-party applications like Snowflake?

  3. Do you foresee any challenges or limitations with the above proposed solutions?

Looking forward to inputs from SAP and community experts who have dealt with similar SAP-to-Snowflake integration scenarios.

entry.title: Re: T.code=MRRL , got an error Enter Business Place Messa...
entry.content:
Creating a dummy business place without GST data (assuming the issue is GST India related) might satisfy the structural requirement, but it fails during accounting document generation because no tax procedure can be applied, no GSTIN or state code is available. SAP cannot determine tax accounts, leading to a dump or error.

Probably, it would have been good had you shared what are the areas you already checked so that, I can skip those. Having said that, check the following once again even if you have already checked

SPRO → Financial Accounting → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transactions → India → Basic Settings → Define Business Place - here check the Business Place is properly defined

SPRO → Financial Accounting → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transactions → India → Basic Settings → Assign Business Place to Plant - here check the Business Place is assigned to plant

Go to tcode J_1IGREG (assuming the issue is GST India related), check whether GST Registration Number is maintained. This links your business place to a valid GSTIN and state code

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Exciting Blog Posts, Countdown for Devtoberfest, and More!
entry.content:
One of the best things about September so far is how our platform has many new improvements, active members, features for developers, location groups, and events. There are many reasons to explore and engage inside SAP Community, but this is the type of month that makes everyone feel more excited to learn, connect, and dive deeply into all topics related to SAP.

This SAP Community Voice newsletter highlights some of these updates, summarizes trending topics, explores details about Devtoberfest, and spotlights opportunities to participate in upcoming virtual and physical events, including SAP TechEd.

Read more below to find out what’s happening in and around SAP Community!

Featured Content

SAP ILM Store Configuration with Microsoft Azure Storage

If you are looking for organized and clear steps on how to configure SAP ILM store with Microsoft Azure Blob, we recommend this content written by @Rahul_Das65. This technical guide covers the prerequisites, authorizations required, certificates, and instructions for testing the connection in the end. To make your life easier, he made sure to include all the sources and useful documents as well.

Read the blog post

AI Agent – First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server

This SAP Fiori MCP (Model Context Protocol) server marks a milestone in SAP’s AI journey by introducing open-source tools for AI coding assistants that you create. In this post, @Christoph_Gollmick explains how MCP helps with large language models (LLMs) to ensure the most reliable results, while also supporting all developers by providing a faster and efficient experience when generating and adapting applications.

Read the blog post

Lessons on SAP Datasphere Architecture

Thinking about building a data solution with SAP Datasphere? This blog post by @haungo can be very helpful. He walks through the steps -- from an initial design to a final, more robust architecture. “Lessons learned” content is always valuable because it provides the insights from the ups and downs of real-world projects.

Read the blog post

New GenAI Feature Available for SAP Integration Suite Version 6.69

SAP´s @DeepakGDeshpande shares details about the new Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediations Steps feature that boosts the efficiency of the development process. The feature is currently available for the premium edition in specific regions/data centers, but SAP will add more as the rollout of the software feature continues.

Read the blog post

Community News

More Kudos, More Badges

If you’re an active member who supports other members by giving them kudos, we are now acknowledging your engagement efforts with a new badge progression set. You’ll earn the first badge in the set with your very first kudo, then receive more badges after giving 30 kudos, then 75, 200, and 500 as the final milestone. Check more details in this What’s New post, which provides a full overview about how this simple act makes such a big impact for our community.

New Design Pilot: We Still Need Your Feedback

In our last edition of SAP Community Voice, we mentioned how we were running a pilot to test a new layout for blog posts that removes widgets and white spaces from the right column, as a way to make the reading experience better. This feature will be available until September 23, so that means another week for you to give us your opinion! You can read more about the pilot in this post and share your feedback in the comments.

New Location Group in Africa

We are so happy that our Middle East and Africa location groups are growing this year. This month we would like to welcome our new Nigeria group, curated by @CharledNwankwo, who has been an active member since 2020. Check now his first blog post on the group here. If you also live in this area, make sure to register to learn and connect with other members from your region and to support future physical events across Nigeria.

Josh Bentley Is Our SAP Community Team Spotlight for September 2025

Our SAP Community team spotlight series features interviews with the SAP colleagues dedicated to our community platform and our members, online and in-person. This month, we are super happy to highlight @josh_bentley (maybe you know him as Josh “BlueBeard”). In his interview with @fatemehzarei_001, Josh gives the details behind the idea of his iconic colorful beard, explains how he got involved with SAP Community, talks about his current role, and offers advice for those new to SAP and the community. Read the full interview and look for other interviews in the series, spotlighting Anne Kathrine Petteroe, Moshe Naveh, and Laura Schmitz,

New SAP Community Hobbies Series!

Last week, SAP's @moshenaveh launched a new blog series designed to shine a light on the hobbies and passions of community members. The main goal is to encourage you to share a bit about yourself. What topics bring you joy, keep you motivated, and help you balance your life? Participation in this series is a great way to connect with and inspire other members. Starting the series with this post, Moshe highlights walking and hiking, and we want to encourage you to read it and learn more about his adventures. If you have a cool hobby, please join the series and share your story with the community. We would love to hear about it!

Upcoming Events

The Countdown Is On: Two Weeks to Devtoberfest 2025

Is everyone ready for the most expected tech virtual festival? Because Devtoberfest is right around the corner to kick off the big SAP TechEd season! Starting on September 29, this free and online event will be full of sessions and activities, covering different topics such as ABAP, fronted tooling, AI innovations, and CAP. Beyond the educational content, the participants can play around with the fun activities prepared for Devtoberfest (and do not require you to show up at a specific time, allowing you more flexibility to take part in everything). Oh, and let´s not forget that the competition is on, and you should definitely check out all the rules and prizes for the Devtoberfest 2025 Contest.

SAP TechEd Agenda Builder

For all our members who are planning to attend SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin next month and need help to plan on what are the best options to participate (we know it is hard to choose with more than 250 different great sessions), we highly recommend the online agenda builder. This tool allows you to browse through all the sessions available, including keynotes, workshops, roadmaps, and much more. It is very simple to add the ones you are interested in attending to your dashboard and have a clear and clean view. This feature is also available for those participating in SAP TechEd Virtual, so you can plan your schedule whether you're joining in person or online.

SAP Inside Track Around the World

In our last SAP Community Voice newsletter, we highlighted that it's now easier to find local events using the new filter "Country”. This new feature helps you discover events not directly linked to a location group (e.g., Portugal and Mexico meet-ups can be found even if not represented by a group), as well as events in these groups. Perhaps, if you explore the list, you will see how many SAP Inside Tracks are going to happen in the next two weeks. We highly recommend that you attend if you are looking to connect in person with other members in your area. To help you find these upcoming events more easily: SAP Inside Track Belgium, SAP Inside Track Warsaw, SAP Inside Track Philadelphia, SAP Inside Track Hamburg, SAP Inside Track Porto, SAP SIT RS (Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil).

entry.title: Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When you start learning CAP, running cds add tiny-sample generates all the necessary sample artifacts, including a CSV file inside the db/data folder. Once deployed, the data from this CSV file is loaded as initial data into SAP HANA Cloud.

This mechanism seems convenient for loading initial data into SAP HANA Cloud for productive applications, doesn’t it?
However, there’s a catch. If you change the CSV data or modify the schema, the data in SAP HANA Cloud will be reinitialized with the CSV content — including the data entered by users! Let’s take a look at what the documentation says:

On SAP HANA, only use CSV files for configuration data that can't be changed by application users. → See CSV data gets overridden in the SAP HANA guide for details.

This is exactly the point I want to highlight in this article. At the same time, I’ve also explored some alternative approaches and validated them.

 

Case1: New Development

When developing a new CAP application, you have the following options:

  • Option A: Do not use CSV files to register initial data for tables that will be maintained by the application.
  • Option B: If both initial data and user-generated data need to coexist, define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata file.

Option A is the simplest, if feasible. However, in some cases — such as for master data — the ability to quickly load initial data from CSV files is attractive. Below, let’s look at Option B in more detail.

 

Option B: Define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata

1. Add a column called dataCategory to the CSV file to distinguish between different types of data. (This is just an example; you can use any column as in identifier.) 

entity Books {
  key ID    : Integer;
      title : String;
      stock : Integer;
      dataCategory: String enum {
        system = 'S';
        user = 'U';
      }
}

2. Run the command cds build --production to generate an .hdbtabledata file in the gen/db/src/data folder. Copy this file to the db/src/static/csv folder, and then add an include_filter as shown below.  This ensures that the HDI container takes ownership only of the records specified by the filter. (Note: The values must be strings, even if the column’s data type is numeric.)

{
  "format_version": 1,
  "imports": [
    {
      ...,
      "import_settings": {
        "import_columns": [
          "ID",
          "TITLE",
          "STOCK",
          "DATACATEGORY"
        ],
        "include_filter": [
          { "DATACATEGORY" : "S" }
        ]
      },
      "column_mappings": {
        "ID": "ID",
        "TITLE": "title",
        "STOCK": "stock",
        "DATACATEGORY": "dataCategory"
      }
    }
  ]
}

3. Move the CSV file into the db/src/static/csv folder as well. Don't forget to set the dataCategory to "S".

ID,title,stock,dataCategory
1,Wuthering Heights,100,S
2,Jane Eyre,500,S

4. After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state (as shown in the result of a GET request):

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. When schema changes or updates to the initial data are applied, records with dataCategory = "S" are overwritten, while records with dataCategory = "U" remain untouched. For example, after adding a new column newField:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 100, "title": "Wuthering Heights" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "newField": null, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Case 2: Accidentally Mixed Data

In some cases, custom data and pre-delivered data (from a CSV file) may accidentally end up in the same table governed by an HDI Table Data artifact (.hdbtabledata) without filter conditions to separate them. 

SAP Note 2922271 outlines how to handle this situation. Below, I’ll walk you through the steps.

Note: The procedure described here applies to single-tenant applications. For multitenant scenarios, please refer to the documentation, as well as @Sekar_Somasundaram's  detailed blog post. 

 

Steps at a Glance

  • Delete the CSV file.
  • Make the .hdbtabledata artifact subject to undeploy.
  • Ensure that existing data is preserved during undeploy.

 

Current State of the Data

  • The CSV file initially contains the following data:

ID,title,stock
1,Wuthering Heights,100
2,Jane Eyre,500

  • After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Step-by-Step: Deleting the CSV File After Initial Deployment

1. Delete the CSV file.

2. Add "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata" to db/undeploy.json as shown below:

[
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbindex",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbconstraint",
  "src/gen/**/*_drafts.hdbtable",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbcalculationview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata"
]

3. Copy gen/db/package.json to the db folder, and add the following parameters to the start script.

 --undeploy src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true

In my example, the package.json looks as follows:

{
  "name": "deploy",
  "dependencies": {
    "hdb": "^0",
    "@sap/hdi-deploy": "^5"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=18"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node node_modules/@sap/hdi-deploy/deploy.js --use-hdb --parameter com.sap.hana.di.table/try_fast_table_migration=true --undeploy src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true"
  }
}

4. Deploy the project. In the db-deployer log, you will see a message indicating that the existing data was not deleted.

[APP/TASK/deploy/0] OUT The "skip_data_deletion" make parameter is set; no data will be deleted from the target table "MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS"

As a result, the updated user data remains intact.

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. Before the next deployment, delete the db/package.json file to restore the original state. From this point on, even if the schema changes, the data will no longer be overridden.

 

Other Ways to Register Data

Besides using CSV files during deployment, you can load data through the following approaches as well:

  • Insert data via HTTP requests: Insert data after deployment using HTTP requests.
  • Upload CSV files through the Database Explorer: Upload CSV files directly from the Database Explorer.
  • For local testing: Place CSV files in the test/data folder instead of db/data (see: Location of CSV Files | CAPire).

 

Closing

A clear strategy on how to provide initial data must be defined upfront. CSV files are convenient but must be used with caution, particularly in productive environments. Applying best practices such as separating system and user data, leveraging .hdbtabledata filters, or considering alternative loading options will help maintain data integrity and protect user input across deployments.

 

References

  • CSV Data Gets Overridden (capire) 
  • I removed sample data (.csv file) from my project. Still, the data is deployed and overwrites existing data. (capire)

entry.title: How to Extract Transactional Data into Migration Files on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are currently working on a project in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition and preparing transactional data (e.g., open POs, sales orders, goods receipts, invoices, open items, balances) for migration and cutover.

While the Migration Cockpit provides standard templates for uploading data, we have not found a straightforward way to extract existing transactional data from the system into these same template formats.

Specifically, we are looking for functionality (standard app, API, or recommended approach) that would allow us to:

Export transactional datasets (by company code, plant, posting period, etc.) directly into migration-compatible files.

Ensure extracted files match SAP migration object templates for reuse.

Improve reconciliation, data validation, and tenant-to-tenant migrations without heavy manual rework.

Has anyone implemented a solution for this in #S/4HANA Public Cloud

Is there a standard app available?

 

Or do we need to leverage Data Migration APIs / CDS Views / SAP Data Services to achieve this?

 

Any guidance, best practices, or references to documentation would be greatly appreciated.

 

#SAP S/4HANA PUBLIC CLOUD

entry.title: Re: Custom Field value is not picked up by SAP21 Customer...
entry.content:
Hello @JastinC1 

When the C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP form’s item node pulls data from I_OperationalAcctgDocItem, your custom field on business context FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM is not automatically included. To resolve this issue, it is necessary to extend the FDP data source to enable the form to access your YY1 field. The feature 'Maintain Data Source Extensions' is particularly useful in this regard. SAP Help Portal-Accounting Document Item: Operational View

Recommended checklist

In Custom Fields: open your YY1 field → Enable Usage for Form Templates and Data Source Extensions → Publish. SAP Help Portal-Creating Custom Fields in SAP S/4HANA Cloud System

In Maintain Data Source Extensions: pick C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP → add your YY1 field by navigating the association to the item (I_OperationalAcctgDocItem) node → Publish. SAP Help Portal: Creating Data Source Extensions

In Maintain Form Templates: re-download/update your template, rebind the new field on the item context, upload it, and test in Create Correspondence. SAP Help Portal

Just a quick note: if your YY1 field doesn’t appear in the association browser when extending C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP, create a tiny Custom CDS View that exposes the YY1 value for the accounting line, then pull it in via the data-source extension path. This is the standard workaround when a field isn’t reachable directly in the FDP’s association graph. SAP Help Portal-Create CDS Views for Debit and Credit Line
GenAI Assisted Content (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition). SAP Help – Custom Fields & Maintain Data Source Extensions; CDS view documents for I_OperationalAcctgDocItem; App Extensibility for Create Correspondence. SAP Help Portal: Creating Data Source Extensions

SAP Learning-Using Custom Fields and Logic

Custom Fields and Logic App F1481

SAP Community blog-Simple extensibility of Data Sources for Output Forms in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: in S/4hana cloud public logistic context, add custom...
entry.content:
Hello @nerevar 

Thank you for your question.

Consider Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic to give you some details. However, the Batch object is currently not released for Key User Extensibility in Public Cloud. This means that you cannot add custom fields to the Batch object while using the custom field logic app.

As you mentioned you can use SAP_COM_0337 but this will only support the standard fields.

Alternatively, if you need to extend the data model, the best practice in public cloud is to create a custom business object or you make use of the side-by-side extension on BTP. This allows you to link your custom object to your batch using the reference key and expose it through OData service and integrate it with your MES.

In regard to ABAP SDK, you cannot extend to the batch tables in public cloud. That approach applies on to on-prem or private cloud deployments.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Extract Transactional Data into Migration File...
entry.content:
Hello @Sesan 

Thank you for your question.

Consider Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit & SAP API Business Hub for details. Please note that the Migration Cockpit only provides upload template for migration objects. There is currently no standard function to automatically export existing transactional data into these sample templates. This is because migration objects are built for inbound loading and not for extraction. However, there are,some best practices you should consider:

  • Using released OData or SOAP APIs to extract your data from your source tenant. Consult S/4HANA Cloud APIs for more details.
  • Accessing released CDS views through custom analytical queries app for your transactional objects. This provides you with the option to filter company code, plant, etc. and export.
  • It is advised to us Data Migration templates. For reconciliation, you will need to export data manually or through APIs. This will enable you transform it into the template format.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Communication Management Translations
entry.content:
Hello @XinXin 

Thank you for your question.

Consider consulting Manage Translations to give you more insights.

However, in Public Cloud not all custom technical objects are supported for translation through the Manage translation app. In public cloud, the technical objects you want to translate them to is not enabled for key user translation.

  • A work around could be to maintain descriptive texts in a single language and ensure you name them consistently.
  • You also have the possibility to raise an influence request if multi-language support is critical for your project. This can be done on the customer influence portal.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Error when using the new App...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Thank you for your question.

These references Import Master Data - Business Partners (New) & Export Master Data will help provide some details. However, considering the import app expects the original XML format generated by the export app, editing the file in Excel could break the XML structure and potentially cause what you are experiencing. Import Master Data - Business Partners (New)

Even if you are moving between tenants, the process still requires a defined source system to be selected in the app. If you don’t define this, it can also cause it to fail.

One more thing to check is if your file size meets the recommendation. If that is the case, I recommend you split it.

Finally, flickering in the UI seems to be a refresh issue. Consider clearing your browser cache or use a different browser. You can also use GUI for HTML access through the app finder.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris
